document.title: The weak and strong laws of large numbers

para.p:
Using Egorov’s theorem, one proves that if a sequence of random variables
X n
converges almost surely to a random variable
X
then
X n
converges in probability to
X
. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1
V. I. Bogachev, Measure Theory, volume I, p. 111, Theorem 2.2.3; http://individual.utoronto.ca/jordanbell/notes/L0.pdf, p. 3, Theorem 3.

Let
X n
be a sequence of
L 1
random variables,
≥ n 1
. A weak law of large numbers is a statement that

converges in probability to
0
. A strong law of large numbers is a statement that () converges almost surely to
0
. Thus, if the hypotheses assumed on the sequence of random variables are the same, a strong law implies a weak law.

We shall prove the weak law of large numbers for a sequence of independent identically distributed
L 1
random variables, and the strong law of large for the same hypotheses. We give separate proofs for these theorems as an occasion to inspect different machinery, although to establish the weak law it thus suffices to prove the strong law. One reason to distinguish these laws is for cases when we impose different hypotheses. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 cf. Jordan M. Stoyanov, Counterexamples in Probability, third ed., p. 163, §15.3; Dieter Landers and Lothar Rogge, Identically distributed uncorrelated random variables not fulfilling the WLLN, Bull. Korean Math. Soc. 38 (2001), no. 3, 605–610.

We also prove Markov’s weak law of large numbers, which states that if
X n
is a sequence of
L 2
random variables that are pairwise uncorrelated and

then
⁢

n

(

0
in
L 2
, from which it follows using Chebyshev’s inequality that it converges in probability to
0
. (We remark that a sequence of
L 2
random variables converging in
L 2
to
0
does not imply that it converges almost surely to
0
, although there is indeed a subsequence that converges almost surely to
0
. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 http://individual.utoronto.ca/jordanbell/notes/L0.pdf, p. 4, Theorem 5.)

para.p:
We now prove a weak law of large numbers, that is sometimes attributed to Markov, that neither supposes that the random variables are independent nor supposes that they are identically distributed. We remind ourselves that if a sequence
Y n
of
L 2
random variables converges to
0
in
L 2
then it converges in probability to
0
; this is proved using Chebyshev’s inequality.

The following lemma gives conditions under which we can establish that a function is measure-preserving. 9 footnote 9 9 footnote 9 Peter Walters, An Introduction to Ergodic Theory, p. 20, Theorem 1.1.

The following statement gives conditions under which a measure-preserving transformation is ergodic, weak-mixing, or strong-mixing. 12 footnote 12 12 footnote 12 Peter Walters, An Introduction to Ergodic Theory, p. 41, Theorem 1.17.

Math.text: P * (T ^ (- n) * A intersection B) to P * A * P * B

Math.text: absent = ((product _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(C _ m) intersection ((product _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ m)

absent = ((product _ (m = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@((C _ m intersection B _ m) * ((product _ (m = n)) ^ infinity)@(C _ m intersection B _ m))

Math.text: P * (tau ^ (- n) * A intersection B) = ((product _ (m = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@((mu _ m * B _ m) cdot ((product _ (m = n)) ^ infinity)@(mu _ m * A _ (m - n)))

We will use Lemma to prove the strong law of large numbers. First we prove two lemmas about joint distributions. 17 footnote 17 17 footnote 17 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Functional Analysis, Princeton Lectures in Analysis, volume IV, p. 208, Lemma 2.2, Lemma 2.3.

Math.text: E _ (list@(k, N, n)) = conditional-set@(omega element-of Omega, absolute-value@(X _ n * omega - a) less= 1 / k)

para.p: Then define

Math.text: E = ((intersection _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((union _ (N = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((intersection _ (n = N)) ^ infinity)@(E _ (list@(k, N, n))))) = ((intersection _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((union _ (N = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ (list@(k, N)))) = ((intersection _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ k)

Math.text: G _ (list@(k, N, n)) = ((intersection _ (m = N)) ^ n)@(E _ (list@(k, N, m)))
H _ (list@(k, N, n)) = ((intersection _ (m = N)) ^ n)@(F _ (list@(k, N, m)))

(

Math.text: P * G _ (list@(k, N, n)) = P ^ prime * H _ (list@(k, N, n))

para.p: But

Math.text: E _ (list@(k, N)) = ((intersection _ (n = N)) ^ infinity)@(E _ (list@(k, N, n))) = ((intersection _ (n = N)) ^ infinity)@(G _ (list@(k, N, n))) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@(G _ (list@(k, N, n)))

para.p: and

Math.text: F _ (list@(k, N)) = (limit _ (n to infinity))@(H _ (list@(k, N, n)))

para.p: so

Math.text: P * E _ (list@(k, N)) = P ^ prime * F _ (list@(k, N))

para.p: Then

Math.text: P * E _ k = (limit _ (N to infinity))@(P * E _ (list@(k, N))) = (limit _ (N to infinity))@(P ^ prime * F _ (list@(k, N))) = P ^ prime * F _ k

para.p: Then

Math.text: P * E = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(P * E _ k) = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(P ^ prime * F _ k) = P ^ prime * F
